Recidivism definition: Reincarcerated within 2 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 66% of juveniles recidivated

Recidivism definition: Reincarcerated within 3 years of release
Other findings: Rates by offense: Robbery (30.3%), Burglary (39.7%), Forgery (32.6%), Rape & Sex Offenses (22.6%), Assault (21.6%), Drugs (24%); Rates by ethnicity & gender: black male (28.7%), white male (28.9%), white female (23.6%), black female (19.8%), male (28.7%), female (21.9%)

Population specifics: 1,798 offenders with at least one felony conviction in 1999
Recidivism definition: Rearrested, new court case filed, reconvicted, and reincarcerated within 3 years of release from prison
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 66% reincarcerated at least once for a new offense or probation/parole violation; 59% arrested at least once for a new offense
Other findings: Younger offenders had higher recidivism rates, property offenders had higher re-arrest rates, sex offenders had lowest re-arrest rates, indigent offenders had 22% higher r -arrest rates than those with private attorneys. Those with alcohol problems had slightly higher recidivism rates (57% compared to 50%). 62% of those with drug problems recidivated compared to 57% of those without drug problems. An offender's ethnicity (if Native), prior criminal history, alcohol, drug and mental health problems were other factors that increased the chance of re-arrest. A great majority of re-arrests had occurred by the end of two years after initial arrest.

Population specifics: 117 offenders participating in  therapeutic courts (alcohol and drug programs) charged mostly with felonies in 1999
Recidivism definition: New arrest or new conviction 1 year after release from program or prison
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 13% of graduates were rearrested within one year after completing a therapeutic court program compared to a 32% rearrest rate for comparison offenders
Other findings: The longer individuals were in programs the less likely they were to recidivate, even if they did not graduate the program. Younger participants more likely to recidivate. Those in DUI court were less likely to be arrested than those in drug court. Blacks did not respond as well to therapeutic programs as whites. Those who were discharged, or voluntarily left, had similar recidivism rates to those not in the programs.

Reported by: Alaska Department of Corrections, Offender Programs, and the Alaska Justice Statistical Analysis Unit, Justice Center, University of Alaska Anchorage.
Population specifics: 685 sex offenders in treatment center from 1987-1995
Recidivism definition: Varied
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Unspecified: those in program longer took longer to reoffend than those in program for shorter periods
Other findings: The study found that any treatment lowered recidivism rates relative to no treatment for sex offenders; for all offenders who completed the advanced stage, none were rearrested for sexual offenses; those with no history of abuse advanced further in the program, and those with a history tended to leave at earlier stages of the program.

Recidivism definition: Reincarceration after 3 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 42.4% returned to custody for any reason, 24.5% returned to custody with a new criminal commitment, 23.2% acquired a new felony conviction, 5.9% acquired a new felony conviction for a violent crime, 30.9% committed a new felony offense, and 7.9% committed a new violent felony offense resulting in recommitment
Other findings: Those who participated in work and education programs, vocational education, and substance abuse treatment had recidivism reduced by an average of 25%. Prison industry programs reduced recidivism by approximately 34%.

Reported by: Arizona Criminal Justice Commission (Statistical Analysis Center Publication)
Population specifics: 538 sex offenders released in 2001; however, n=290 because the status of 232 of these individuals labeled as sex offenders could not be confirmed and were subsequently excluded from the study sample.
Recidivism definition: Percent rearrested for any type of crime
Other findings: 58% of non-sex offenders were rearrested for a new crime within 3 years of release. 56.7% of sex offenders who were rearrested were charged with a felony. This is higher than the 41.6% of non-sex offenders who were rearrested for a felony offense. Latino men (45.8%) released in 2001 were more likely than Caucasian men (22.8%) to be rearrested for a new crime within the first 3 years of release. Latino men (5.1%) and black men (3.0%) had the highest rearrest rates for another sex crime compared to Caucasian men (1.9%).The younger the prisoner when released, the higher the rate of recidivism--63.3% of offenders under the age of 25 at release were rearrested for some type of crime within 3 years compared to 21% of those age 45 or older.

Recidivism definition: Reincarcerated within 3 years of release from prison
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 47.4% of all those released in 2003 were reincarcerated by 2006; 44.4% of all those released in 2004 were reincarcerated by 2007
Other findings: Those on parole experienced higher rates of recidivism than those were simply discharged. Males age 25-34 were shown to be most at risk of recidivating, as were those 18-24 years old.

Recidivism definition: Reincarcerated within 3 years of release from prison starting from 2002
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 49.4% of persons released in 2002 were reincarcerated by 2005
Other findings: Of the 5, 841 parolees released, 2,938 or 50.3% recidivated. Of the 174 offenders discharged, 31, or 17.8% recidivated. At the end of the 3-year period, African Americans, who accounted for 2,618 releases, recidivated at a slightly higher rate (51%) than Caucasians (49%), who accounted for 3,292 of releases; The return rate for Hispanics was significantly less at 17.3%, accounting for 75 releases in 2002.

Recidivism definition: Reincarcerated within 3 years of release from prison starting from 2001
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 51.4% of persons released in 2001 were reincarcerated by 2004
Other findings: Parolees demonstrated a 52.6% recidivism rate while discharged persons experienced a 12.5% recidivism rate.  African Americans recidivated at a slightly higher recidivism rate  (54%) than Caucasians (50%) while 28% of Hispanics recidivated.

Reported by: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation
Recidivism definition: Reincarcerated within 1 year of release, and reincarcerated within 2 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 52.7% recidivism rate after 2 years for all felons.

Reported by: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation
Recidivism definition: Reincarcerated within 1, 2, and 3 years of release; ratio of the number of recidivists (number returned) to the number of felons at risk of recidivating (number paroled) during the specified period.
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 39.9% recidivism rate after 1 year; 54.2% recidivism rate after 2 years, and 59% recidivism rate after 3 years.

Reported by: California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation
Recidivism definition: Reincarcerated within 1 year of release, and reincarcerated within 2 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 40.2% recidivism rate after 1 year; 52.3% recidivism rate after 2 years.

Reported by: Office of Research and Statistics, Division of Criminal Justice, Colorado Department of Public Safety.
Population targeted by study: Felons who participated in community programs
Population specifics: 20, 385 offenders who either successfully completed or unsuccessfully completed stays with halfway houses between 2000-2004. Successful completion included program completion and transfer to non-residential community corrections status, on probation/parole supervision, or completion of sentence. Unsuccessful completion involved new crime and warrants or absconding or escaping.
Recidivism definition: New misdemeanor or felony within 1 year and 2 years of release.
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 26.8% recidivated after 2 years.
Other findings: Employed individuals were less likely to recidivate as were people with more education; whites were less likely to recidivate than black and Latino ex-offenders, married individuals were less likely to recidivate than single ex-offenders.

Recidivism definition: Return to prison within 3 years of release from prison.
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 49.8% recidivated after 3 years

Recidivism definition: Return to prison within 3 years of release from prison.
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 49% recidivated after 3 years
Other findings: Comprehensive study, reports on other studies: GED attainment helps find employment post-release, which then reduces recidivism rates. Drug treatment programs (therapeutic communities) reduce recidivism and are just as effective for those who are coerced into treatment as those who enter voluntarily. One study done by the Center for Court Innovation (CCI) in New York. found recidivism rates for drug court participants was 29% lower than for similar offenders who did not participate in drug court

Reported by: Department of Corrections and Central Connecticut State University’s Institute for the Study of Crime and Justice
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within the 5 year period between 2001-2006
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 39% reconviction rate
Other findings: 47% recidivated who were not given supervision post-release.  Supervision in halfway house significantly reduced recidivism, to 24% (or half of the reconviction rate of those unsupervised).

Reported by: Office of Policy & Management, Criminal Justice Policy and Planning Division, Research, Analysis and Evaluation Unit
Recidivism definition: 3 year follow-up; 1) new arrests 2) new convictions 3) any incidence of re-incarceration, 4) returns to prison with a new sentence
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Within 3 years of release: 67% arrested for new offense, 55.6% convicted of new offense, 56% were incarcerated (any reincarceration), 36.7% reincarcerated for new offenses
Other findings: Those released to half-way houses were less likely to be rearrested (63.7%), reconvicted (51.7%), and reincarcerated (35.5%) across the release cohort. For example, probationers and those under transitional supervision were rearrested, reconvicted, and reincarcerated at rates of 70.8%, 59%, and 41.7%. Those in transitional supervision were rearrested at 71.7%, reconvicted at 57.8%, and reincarcerated at 37.3% of the time. Modest decline in reincarceration rate for new offense from 2006 study.

Population targeted by study: Felons who participated in conflict resolution program
Population specifics: 300 male felons who voluntarily participated in Alternative to Violence Program
Program type (if any): Alternatives to Violence Conflict Resolution Program
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 1, 2, and 3 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 11.5% reconvicted within 3 years of release
Other findings: Compared to recidivism rates of non-participants, those who participated in the conflict resolution program were reconvicted less often.  But these individuals may differ since they volunteered to participate in the program.

Recidivism definition: Reincarceration within 30-36 months after release

Population targeted by study: Felons who participated in drug courts
Population specifics: 452 probation-violators with substance abuse problems sentenced to drug courts between October of 1993 and March of 1997
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of graduation from drug court
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 33% of drug court graduates were reconvicted,  80% of those who were dismissed or left voluntarily before graduating were reconvicted
Other findings: Those coded as violent offenders (for charges prior to drug court) were significantly more likely to re-offend post release from drug court, and more likely to reoffend with a violent offense (almost 25% compared to less than 10% for those coded as non-vi

Reported by: Delaware Juvenile Drug Court Diversion Program
Population specifics: 154 first-time juvenile offenders admitted to therapeutic diversion program in 2 Delaware counties
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 1 year of release or termination of program
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 35% of graduates recidivated compared to 60% who did not complete the program
Other findings: A matched comparison group showed a 50% recidivism rate

Reported by: Office of Management and Budget Statistical Analysis Center
Recidivism definition: Rearrest and reincarceration within 5 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 77% rearrested  within 5 years of release, 41% rearrested for a new sex crime and 64% rearrested for a felony within 5 years of release
Other findings: Black juvenile sex offenders (41%) were more likely to be rearrested than white juvenile sex offenders (36%).

Reported by: Office of Management and Budget Statistical Analysis Center
Recidivism definition: Rearrest within 3 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 71.8% rearrested for any new crime or violation of probation/parole
Other findings: Overall recidivism was higher for blacks than whites.

Reported by: Office of Management and Budget Statistical Analysis Center
Program type (if any): Serious and Violent offender Reentry Initiative (SVORI)
Recidivism definition: Rearrest for a new felony within one year of starting the SVORI program
Other findings: 63.5% for those who completed SVORI program, compared to 82.1% for offenders who did not complete the program. For Hispanic males (n=17) the SVORI participants were arrested within one year (100%), while the remaining 13 males who did not participate, were least likely to recidivate (69.2%). White females had the best outcomes among those who participated and completed the SVORI program. White females also had the lowest rearrest rate (41.7%), followed by black females at 66.7% and were less likely to complete SVORI compared to white females. At about the same successful completion rate, black males recidivated (68.5%) at a higher rate than white males (52.9%).

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison

Reported by: Office of Management and Budget Statistical Analysis Center
Population specifics: 1,048 released from Level V residential placement; 2,354 released from Level IV placement; 3,964 released from Level III placement
Program type (if any): Locked secure facility (level V), staff secure (level IV) or a non-secure program (level III); levels define intensity of programming and residential placement; synonymous with idea of max-med-low security facilities
Recidivism definition: Rearrest for a felony within 6,12,18,24, and 36 months
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Level V locked secure facility: 43% rearrested; Level IV staff secure programs: 40% arrested; Level III non-secure program: 30% rearrested.

Reported by: District of Columbia Department of Corrections
Recidivism definition: Reincarceration within 1 year
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 23% for all inmates

Recidivism definition: Reconviction and reimprisonment within 60 months of release from prison
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 55.8%, 38.7%, and 41.6% of black, other race, and Hispanic males reoffended. 44.2%, 40.5%, and 35.8% of black, other race, and Hispanic females reoffended. Similarly, 45.1%, 28.1%, and 31.7% of black, other race and Hispanic males were reimprisoned, while 25.4%, 23.2%, and 19.9% of black, other race, and Hispanic females were reimprisoned
Other findings: Female inmates reoffend at a lower rate than males, the reoffense rates of inmates over age 44 at release (the largest category) are about 22 percentage points lower than inmates aged 18 to 24 (the smallest category), 15% more Blacks reoffend than whites, those with lower education reoffend more than those with slightly higher educational attainment.

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison
Other findings: 28%, down from 37% in 2006 after instituting "Risk Reduction Services"

Recidivism definition: Rearrest, reconviction, or reincarceration within 2 years of release from juvenile facility
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 82% rearrested, 57.3% reconvicted, 32.2% reincarcerated

Population specifics: 1,200 Offenders who whose risk was assessed and various levels of supervision were given based on risk level
Program type (if any): Levels of Service Inventory Revised (LSI-R) risk assessment tool
Recidivism definition: Rearrest within 6 months of release and categorized by different levels associated with LSIR, meaning offenders with high probabilities of offending were given services that corresponded with the various levels of LSI-R. Such levels included (1) administrative; or no LSI-R assessment, (2) low, (3) medium, (4) high levels, and (5) Surveillance, which corresponded with use of LSI-R risk assessments for offenders that scores offenders based on needs
Finding or Recidivism Rate: In order of level categorized: Administrative 22.6%, Low 32.9%, Medium 42.2%, High 41.6%, Surveillance 42.2%
Other findings: Basically the LSI-R is a good predictor of recidivism rates in Hawaii.  Takes into account offender's current age, age at first conviction, prior arrests, etc.

Recidivism definition: Previous discharged offenders, probationers, and parolees who are reincarcerated, revoked, or incarcerated for a new crime within 5 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 74% of discharged offenders recidivate within 5 years; 82% of probationers recidivate within 30 months and declines to 12% after 3 years; 83% of parolees recidivate within 2 years and declines to 6% after 3 years.
Other findings: 50% of probationers who recidivate will do so within one year, 83% within 2 years.

Population targeted by study: Felons who participated in drug courts
Population specifics: Felons who participated in drug courts
Recidivism definition: Rearrest and reincarceration within an average of 419 days and 1,243 days respectively
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 80% of drug court graduates were not rearrested and only 8% committed drug offenses
Other findings: Those who failed to complete the program had a 60% rearrest rate; 53% of those in the comparison group recidivated

Recidivism definition: Juveniles who are adjudicated for a second offense during supervision or within one year of release from MDOC supervision
Other findings: Drug and alcohol offenses accounted for 18% of all new adjudications.

Population targeted by study: Gang members released in 2000 from IL prison
Population specifics: All inmates released from IL prison in 2000 (2,354 inmates) 26% of whom were considered to be active gang members
Recidivism definition: Rearrest and re-incarceration within about 26 months (2.2 years) from release in 2000
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 75% of active gang members rearrested, about 63% of non-gang members rearrested
Other findings: Gang members were more likely to be arrested for drug crimes (40%) than non-gang members (29%)

Reported by: University of Missouri, St. Louis submitted to ICJIA
Recidivism definition: Rearrest within 4 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Treatment completers had a recidivism rate of 37% after four years, those who failed out of treatment had a recidivism rate of 67% after four years. Drug users without any treatment had a 53% recidivism rate after four years.
Other findings: Probationers with a history of drug abuse significantly more likely to be rearrested post-probation: within four years 1.4 times as likely and 1.3 times as likely to be rearrested on a drug-related charge.

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison
Other findings: Nearly 50% of those charged with weapons charges recidivated; the younger the offenders were the more likely they were to recidivate; sex offenders were the most likely to recidivate

Recidivism definition: Reincarceration within 3 years of release from prison
Finding or Recidivism Rate: A third (34%) of juveniles recidivated
Other findings: Nearly 38% of African American juvenile offenders returned to the DOC, a higher rate than both Caucasian and Hispanic offenders; 74% of juveniles returned for a new crime, as opposed to a technical violation

Reported by: Human Rights Division of Criminal and Juvenile Justice Planning Statistical Analysis Center
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 5 years of release from prison in FY 96
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 31.7% of parolees, and 35.2% of releases whose sentences expired
Other findings: Violent offenders returned at lower rates than non-violent offenders, and sex offenders had the lowest rate of recidivism. Violent young offenders (under 21) had the highest recidivism rates of any offense/age group

Population targeted by study: Felons participating in re-entry program: Serious Offender Accountability Restoration (SOAR)
Population specifics: 240 Offenders ( 208 adults and 32 juveniles) divided into an experimental group (N=208) and a control group (N=121)
Recidivism definition: Felon reconviction and reincarceration for a new crime within 2 years of release from prison
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 26% were reconvicted compared to 20% of control group
Other findings: SOAR participants had significantly greater criminal histories than offenders in the control group, despite random assignment

Reported by: Iowa Department of Human Rights, Division of Criminal and Juvenile Justice Planning and Statistical Analysis Center
Population specifics: 434: 2 groups of sex offenders (201 pre-registry and 233 registry)
Recidivism definition: Reconviction for any sex crime, non-sex crime, and revocation of parole or probation within 4.3 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 24.5% of registry sex offenders were convicted of a new crime, 3.0% of which were sex crimes. 33.3% pre-registry sex offenders were convicted of a new crime, 3.5% of which were sex crimes.
Other findings: Almost a fifth (18%) of new convictions were out-of-state convictions

Reported by: Division of Criminal and Juvenile Justice Planning
Recidivism definition: New arrests (felony, violent), reincarceration, and new arrest for a sex crime within 3 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 52.2% of violent offender releases were rearrested within 3 years; 28.6%violent offender releases were reincarcerated within 3 years; and 23.6% of violent offender releases were convicted of a new offense and reincarcerated within 3 years
Other findings: Native Americans showed the highest rates of recidivism after 3 years. African Americans generally showed higher recidivism rates than Caucasians. Those released without parole had rates of new violent felonies 43% higher than those released on parole.

Reported by: Iowa Department of Human Rights, Division of Criminal and Juvenile Justice Planning
Recidivism definition: Delinquency complaints within 3 years of initial complaint
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 34% reoffended and 66% did not reoffend in 8 out 9 districts within Iowa.

Reported by: Cindy J. Smith, Ph.D. and Jennifer Bechtel, M.S.
Recidivism definition: New arrest, conviction, and incarceration in less than 2 years and up to 4.5 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 52.2% were not rearrested, 66.9% were not convicted, and 95.2% were not reincarcerated. Compared to the control groups--work in traditional correctional industries and other than work (no industry work/job)--the rates of success are comparable

Population targeted by study: Felons who participated in various programs
Program type (if any): Variety of program participants evaluated, including: sex offender program, 3 kinds of substance abuse programs, vocational education program, pre-release program, work release program, inner change program
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 1, 2 and 3 years of release from program
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Rates of reconviction: Sex offender program (37.5%), Substance Abuse Treatment Program: ADAPT (37.5%), Substance Abuse Treatment Program: CDRP (30.7%), Substance Abuse Treatment Program: TC (31.4%), Vocational Education Program (39%), Pre-Release Program (46.1%), Work Release Program (32.6%), Inner Change (28.1%), TTP (85.7%)
Other findings: Sex offender treatment was the most beneficial; those who needed program but didn't receive treatment recidivated at a rate of 56.1% vs. those who were in the program recidivating at 37.7%; Substance abuse treatment (3 types) had beneficial outcomes; those who received treatment recidivated at slightly lower rates than those who needed treatment and did not receive it.

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 2 years of release from prison
Other findings: Violent offenders had higher recidivism rates than other groups; those with supervised release returned in greater numbers than those who were discharged; a higher percentage of blacks returned than whites

Reported by: Louisiana Department of Public Safety and Corrections
Recidivism definition: Reconviction or technical revocation within 5 years

Any individual who records a first adjudication in Maine's juvenile court system for offenses committed before the age of 18 and records a second adjudication for a new offense in Maine's juvenile court system or Maine's adult court system
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 27% (a significant increase compared to the 2004 cohort rate of 18%)
Other findings: Juveniles tracked into the adult system also maintained higher recidivism rates (24%) than the previous year. Drug and alcohol offenses accounted for 22% of adjudications for first time juvenile offenders

Recidivism definition: An arrest (or ticket, and summons) for any municipal, state, or federal misdemeanor or felony crime measured within 6 months, 1 year, 2 years, and 3 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 25.4% after 1 year of release

Population targeted by study: Felons: comparing those in education programs to those not in education programs
Recidivism definition: Rearrest, reconviction, and reincarceration
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Participants had a 30.9% reincarceration rate; non-participants had a 37.7% reincarceration rate

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 39% (or 35% without technical violations)
Other findings: Recidivists tended to be younger, unmarried, and to have served shorter sentences, and blacks recidivated at higher rates than whites. Non-violent offenders recidivated at higher rates than violent offenders. Drug offenders serving mandatory minimums had lower recidivism rates than those serving non-mandatory sentences. Parolees had higher recidivism rates than those who were released because of sentence expiration.

Recidivism definition: Felony arrest within 2 years of release from juvenile facility
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 37% for felony arrest and 10% for incarceration
Other findings: Recidivism rates were higher for minorities

Recidivism definition: Reconvicted within 3 years of release from prison
Other findings: 19% of Minnesota’s offenders are returned to prison with a new crime within three years

Population specifics: 3,166 sex offenders released from a state correctional facility between 1990 and 2002
Program type (if any): Sex offender treatment and post-release supervision
Recidivism definition: Rearrest, reconviction, and reincarceration for a new crime; Average follow-up was 8.4 years, with a minimum of 3 years and maximum of 16 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: After 3 years, 7 % rearrested for a sex offense, 6% reconvicted, and 3% reincarcerated; after 3 years, 24% of the offenders has been rearrested for a non-sex offense, 19% reconvicted, and 9% reincarcerated.
Other findings: Intensive supervised release (ISR), supervised release, supervised release revocations (amount of time spent in prison for supervised released violations and deducted from total at-risk time), and successful participation/completion of sex offender treatment each significantly reduced the risk of timing to a sex reoffense; longer post-release supervision period and offenders with a history of victimizing male children significantly reduced the risk timing to a non-sexual offense

Recidivism definition: Referral to the juvenile office for a legally sufficient law violation (ordinance violations, misdemeanor, or felony) during a calendar year and receives one or more law violation(s) to juvenile or adult court within one year of initial referral's disposition date.
Other findings: 29% male offenders reoffend within 12 months, compared to 19% of females. 31% of black youth return to the care of juvenile authorities through recidivating, followed by American Indian offenders (26%), and white offenders (24%).

Population specifics: 808 sex offenders who completed a sex offender program
Program type (if any): STATIC-99 Sex offender program (risk assessment tool)
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 29.7% within three years
Other findings: 0.6% convicted of a new sex offense; 60% of high risk sex offenders returned within 3 years, 26.3% for moderate-high risk offenders, 32.3% for low-moderate risk offenders, and 18.2% for low risk sex offenders

Recidivism definition: Reincarceration and new conviction within 6 months, 1, 2, 3, and 5 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Recidivism rates are lowest under a probation sentence, increases with Community Structured Supervision (CSS) sentences, and is highest for prison and shock and treatment programs.
Other findings: When the recommended sentence of probation is imposed (occurs 77% of the time), recidivism rates are low. However, when the recommended sentence is probation and actual sentence is prison, recidivism rates are much higher, whether measured by new conviction or reincarceration. The same high trend of recidivism continues if the scenario is reversed.

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 2 years of release from prison
Other findings: Those released from Home Confinement had lower recidivism rates than those released from secure facilities. Those in substance abuse treatment programs had about a 23% recidivism rate, lower than those with abuse issues who did not complete treatment

Reported by: University of Montana-Missoula/Montana Department of Corrections
Population targeted by study: Felons who participated in sex offender or drug abuse treatment
Program type (if any): Sex Offender Treatment & Drug abuse treatment
Recidivism definition: Adult offender who returns to prison within 3 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Drug/chemical dependence treatment rate: 55.3% of compliant participants recidivated compared to 77% of those without any treatment. 38.2% of treatment compliant sex offenders recidivated.
Other findings: For those in the drug abuse treatment program, the longer the sentence, the higher the recidivism rate.  Drug treatment had best impact on white inmates who were under 40 at time of release.

Reported by: University of Montana-Missoula/Montana Department of Corrections
Recidivism definition: Within calendar year 2002 and FY 2004-2005
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 55%  who were discharged from pre-release centers did not recidivate, while 45% were reincarcerated
Other findings: Persons coming from prisons (to pre-release center) were significantly less likely to recidivate than those coming from other referral sources

Reported by: University of Montana-Missoula/Montana Department of Corrections
Program type (if any): Medical Wheel (Native American based chemical dependency program) & Anger Management treatment
Recidivism definition: Return to prison for any reason within 3 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Overall recidivism rate was 22.7% (N=5): for treatment population, 17.6% (N=3) and 40% for the non-treatment population (N=2).
Other findings: Those inmates who completed medicine wheel had lower rates of recidivism than those in the comparable non-treatment group. The same follows for inmates who completed the anger management treatment. Native American inmates benefited more from the medicine wheel treatment, but not anger management treatment, where they were more likely to return to prison

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison
Readmission within 3 years of release from prison
Reincarceration as a result of a new sentence or parole or probation revocation within three years of release
Other findings: Recidivism rate for males was 45.2%; females 34.6%; males younger than 25 had highest recidivism rate (52.8%) while females between 20-25 and in their forties recidivated 41.7% and 40% of the time, respectively. Offenders convicted of drug crimes had the lowest recidivism rate (36.5%) compared to those convicted of violent crimes (40.3%), public order crimes (47.6%), and property crimes (50.2%).

Reported by: New Jersey Department of Corrections Research and Evaluation Unit
Population specifics: Random sample of 336 homicide offenders; Typology used: 1) homicide precipitated by a general altercation or argument, 2) homicide during the commission of a felony, 3) domestic violence-related homicide, and 4) a homicide relating to an accident (involuntary; usually DUI related)
Recidivism definition: Committing another homicide within 5 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 0% for new homicides
Other findings: Slightly over 1/3 recidivism rate for new violent and drug offenses in the felony homicide group; 27% recidivism rate for homicide offenders whose offenses were precipitated by an altercation; less than 10% for domestic violence homicide offenders

Reported by: New Jersey Department of Corrections Research and Evaluation Unit
Population specifics: 718 sex offenders released in 1994 and 1997 (495 in treatment group and 223 general population)
Recidivism definition: Rearrest, reconviction, and reincarceration within 4 years (1997 cohort) and 7 years (1994 cohort) which is then divided into nonsexual recidivism and sexual recidivism
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 33% recidivated by committing a new offense, including 14% committing a sexual offense and 24% a nonsexual offense.
Other findings: Significant differences exist between offenders who received treatment in the Adult Diagnostic Treatment Center (ADTC), a sex-offender-specific prison, and the general population in regard to nonsexual reoffending only

Recidivism definition: Rearrest, reconviction, and reincarceration rate
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 55% rearrested, 43% reconvicted, and 31% reincarcerated
Other findings: Of those offenders rearrested, about half were rearrested within 9 months of release

Population specifics: 62 juveniles who exited the juvenile drug court program between 2001-2002
Recidivism definition: Any referral to the Juvenile Justice Department, or any new arrest as an adult (exposure time varied)
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Juvenile drug court graduates recidivated at rate of 28%
Other findings: Compared to similar subjects who did not receive drug court treatment, those who participated in the program had much lower recidivism rates

Reported by: New York State Division of Probation and Correctional Alternatives
Population specifics: 19, 837 sex offenders on sex offender registry
Recidivism definition: New arrest, charge, conviction or incarceration  within 2 years of registration
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 24% arrested for a new crime

Reported by: New York State Division of Probation and Correctional Alternatives
Recidivism definition: Felony rearrest within 1,2, and 3 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 12.4% rearrested within 1 year, 20.1% within 2 years and 25.7% within 3 years
Other findings: Probationers were  less likely to be rearrested for a felony drug offense than for a felony offense defined as "other" or for a violent felony offense

Reported by: North Carolina Sentencing and Policy Advisory Commission
Recidivism definition: Rearrest, reconviction, and reincarceration within 3 years; Two interim outcomes also measured: technical revocation of probation or post-release supervision and prison infractions during incarceration
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 38.7% rearrested, 26.4% reconvicted, and 29.1% reincarcerated
Other findings: Most rearrests occurred within the first year of release, Factors that decreased the probability of rearrest included being married, employed, having at least twelve years of education, having a felony as the current conviction, having a longer prison sentence imposed, and having more prior incarcerations. Age also decreased an offender’s chance of rearrest, with offenders being less likely to be rearrested as they grew older. Those with post-release supervision had lower rearrest rates than those without PRS. Ages 21 and younger had the highest recidivism rates.

Reported by: North Carolina Sentencing and Policy Advisory Commission
Recidivism definition: All subsequent delinquent complaints and adult arrests within 3 years following first court event of sample period (June 1, 2004--June 30, 2005)
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Overall recidivism rate: 56.6%
Other findings: Violent juvenile offenders were least likely to recidivate (39.8%) compared to serious (57.5%) and minor offense (56.9%) juvenile offenders.

Population specifics: 90 juveniles who participated in drug courts by 2004
Recidivism definition: Rearrest within 4 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: For the first drug court evaluated, East Central Judicial District, graduates were more likely to be charged with a substance abuse violation (50%) than those terminated from the program (48%) and the comparison group (21%). Conversely, for the second drug court evaluated, Northeast Central Judicial District graduates were less likely (12%) to be charged with a substance abuse violation than those terminated (38%) and the comparison group (21%). However, this latter finding is not statistically significant. Differences between the two drug courts may be attributed to different lengths of stay at each drug court and late admission to the East Central drug court.
Other findings: Those who did not complete the program because of termination due to age (becoming 18 before completion) or other factors had higher recidivism rates than the comparison group. The older participants had higher rates of recidivism (closer to 18, many of which probably terminated because of this fact)

Reported by: Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Corrections
Population targeted by study: Felons participating in Ohio Penal Industry program
Population specifics: Felons participating in Ohio Penal Industry program
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 5 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: OPI group recidivated at 54%, comparison group recidivated at 58% : differences not statistically significant
Other findings: Blacks had higher recidivism rates overall.

Reported by: Ohio Department of Rehabilitation and Corrections
Recidivism definition: Reconviction for any offense within 10 years
Other findings: 22.3% for new crime (sex crime and others), 11.7% for technical violation

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison
Other findings: Under 20 years old recidivated at 43%, those above 50 recidivated at 9.6%, Black males more likely to recidivate than white males, The most recent survival analyses of institutional treatment programs find that completers of all Oklahoma DOC programs have lower return rates after at least 36 months than program non-participants. Adult Basic Education has proven to be Oklahoma's most successful program. The Level of Service Inventory- Revised (LSI-R) at reception, ranks offenders as low, medium, or high in terms of risk levels for further offending and needs for services to prevent future recidivism. Survival analysis of those offenders released in FY 2004 found that 36 months later, 7% of low LSI-R offenders had returned to DO 32% of medium LSI-R offenders, and 70% of high LSI-R offenders.

Recidivism definition: Reincarceration within 3 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Low risk offenders had the lowest recidivism rate (11%), while high risk offenders returned to prison at a higher rate (14%).
Other findings: Low risk and high risk offenders did better if released to probation and parole instead of immediate discharge from ODOC

Recidivism definition: Reconviction of new felony within 3 years of release from prison

Reported by: Oregon Department of Corrections Research and Statistics
Recidivism definition: Reconviction of any felony within 3 years of release from prison
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Paroled offender 2005 cohort: 29.3%; Probation 2005 cohort: 24.2%

Recidivism definition: Return to custody of a Pennsylvania state correctional institution for any reason
Finding or Recidivism Rate: At three years post release in 1999, the recidivism rate was 43.6. In 2002 the 3 year recidivism rate was 46.3%. At one year post release in 2004, the recidivism rate was 25.9%

Recidivism definition: Overall recidivism: rearrest, reconviction, or reimprisonment following release from prison in 2001 or 2002
Finding or Recidivism Rate: COR completers had a slightly higher overall recidivism rate (71%) compared to the control group (70.1%)
Other findings: Both groups had rearrest and reconviction rates lower than national rates. Racial composition of study population: 53.4% African Americans comprised COR completers and 55.2% of the control group. Whites accounted for 35.5% of COR completers and 31.8% of the control group. And Hispanics made up 10.9% of the COR completers and 12.5% of the control group.

Recidivism definition: Convicted by the courts and sentenced on more than one occasion
Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison
Other findings: Those on probation had highest recidivism rate at 43.7% Under 25 had the highest age group recidivism rate at 44.2%, some work programs had a minimal impact on recidivism, with the best program being Labor Crew with a rate of 27.2%

Recidivism definition: Rearrested and reconvicted within 3 years
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 43% rearrested for any type of crime, 22.3% reconvicted and reincarcerated
Other findings: From the number of sex offenders released from prison in 2001, blacks made up 50% of those rearrested within 3 years, white 37.3%, and  25% other racial/ethnic groups. Young offenders between the ages of 18-29 were more likely to reoffend within 3 years

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison

Reported by: Tennessee Bureau of Investigation Crime Statistics Unit
Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Sex Offenders: 55.9%, Other Offenders (comparison group): 77.8%
Other findings: Of general offenders, the most frequent recommitment was for a technical violation (18.2%); No statistically significant differences between race of recidivists.

Recidivism definition: Reconviction within 3 years of release from prison
Other findings: 48% of recidivists were African American, property and drug offenses make up over 60% combined of recidivist crimes, annually parole violators make up 25% of prison admissions.

Recidivism definition: Reincarceration for any offense in 3 year period of release
Parole violation or reincarceration within 2 years and 7 months
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Participants had recidivism rate of 65%, non-participants 82%
Other findings: 12% recidivated more than once (returning to prison repeatedly), compared to 31.5% of control group recidivating more than once.

Recidivism definition: Offense occurring within 3 year period of release
Offense occurring within 3 year period of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 50% for persons released in 2004 and 60% for persons released in 1994

Recidivism definition: Rearrest, Reconviction, and reincarceration after 12 months of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Releases from juvenile correction centers: 49.4% rearrested, 37.6% reconvicted, and 17.2% reincarcerated. Probation placements: 34.8% rearrested and 24.8% reconvicted; reincarceration data not applicable
Other findings: Black juveniles had higher reoffense rates than white juveniles, those who were released at age 15 had highest rearrest rates, those who participated youth industries program and Virginia Wilderness Institute had lower recidivism rates than those who did not

Recidivism definition: Returned to prison for a new crime or technical parole violation within 3 years of release
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 29% (28% for technical violations and 72% for a new offense)
Other findings: The total recidivism rate was higher in the first two years of being released (2000 & 2001); 29% of those who recidivated came back in 2000 and 26% came back in 2001; 72% of persons were returned for the same type of crime for which they were originally incarcerated

Recidivism definition: Reconviction, length of time not factored into study
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 65% of males, 50% of females
Other findings: 54.6% of those 15-24 recidivated and 65.6% of those 25-34; 73% of African American men recidivated compared to 65% of Caucasian men and 51% of Hispanic men.  Property and drug offenses were the most common re-offense type.

Recidivism definition: Any disposition (sentence) in which the offender's juvenile history contains a disposition (sentence); length of time between convictions not factored into report because database used does not contain data relating to dates of release from confinement
Finding or Recidivism Rate: 77% rate for boys and 72% rate for girls
Other findings: African Americans accounted for 3.9% of the Washington population, but accounted for 13.1% of all juvenile dispositions and had a recidivism rate of 78.1%. Recidivism rate of Hispanics, 82.3%, was highest of all racial groups with Caucasian rate at 75.1% and Asian/Pacific Islanders at 65.1%

Recidivism definition: Return to the custody of the Division of Corrections within a measured amount of time after release; within 3 years for this study
Other findings: Those on parole release (37%) had higher recidivism rates than those discharged (9.5%) or released by court order (26.1%); 25-29 year olds had the highest rate of recidivism by age group followed by 18-24 year olds.

Recidivism definition: Reconviction in a 23 year period
Other findings: American Indians most likely to recidivate (45%) followed by black (43%), Hispanic (37%), white (33%) and Asian/Pacific Islander (24%) offenders. American Indian and black offenders made up 3% and 22% of the offender group, but recidivate at the highest rates.

Recidivism definition: Reconviction or revocation within 3 years of release from prison or supervision
Finding or Recidivism Rate: Released from prison: 10.3%; released from probation: 44.6%  and parole: 33.1%
